            </div>
          </div>
        </div>
      </section> 
    <section class="section blog-contents"> 
      <div class="pa blog-editor">
        <div class="l-container">
          <div class="be__wrapper">
            <div class="be__contents">
              <div class="be__contents-wrapper">
                <p class="wpml-ls-statics-post_translations wpml-ls">This post is also available in: 
    <span class="wpml-ls-slot-post_translations wpml-ls-item wpml-ls-item-ja wpml-ls-first-item wpml-ls-last-item wpml-ls-item-legacy-post-translations"><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.jp/alloy-taurus-targets-se-asian-government/" class="wpml-ls-link"><span class="wpml-ls-native" lang="ja">日本語</span><span class="wpml-ls-display"><span class="wpml-ls-bracket"> (</span>Japanese<span class="wpml-ls-bracket">)</span></span></a></span></p><h2><a id="post-130156-_50qt2dixcmnj"></a><strong>Executive Summary</strong></h2>
<p>We observed a series of intrusions directed at a Southeast Asian government target, a cluster of activity that we attribute with a moderate level of confidence to Alloy Taurus, a group believed to be operating on behalf of Chinese state interests. The multiwave intrusions, which started in early 2022 and persisted throughout 2023, capitalized on vulnerabilities in Exchange Servers to deploy a large number of web shells.</p>
<p>These web shells served as gateways for the introduction of additional tools and malware, some specially crafted for the target environments. These incursions were consistent with techniques used for long-term espionage operations and appeared to be attempts to establish a resilient foothold within the compromised networks.</p>
<p>We found this activity as part of an investigation into <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/analysis-of-three-attack-clusters-in-se-asia" target="_blank" rel="noopener">compromised environments within a Southeast Asian government</a>. We identified this cluster of activity as CL-STA-0045.</p>
<p>Drawing upon available telemetry and threat intelligence, we attribute this cluster of activity with a moderate level of confidence to the Alloy Taurus group, also known as GALLIUM. This group is widely believed to operate on behalf of Chinese state interests and has been observed in multiple espionage campaigns targeting telecommunication companies and government entities across Southeast Asia, Europe and Africa.</p>
<p>Our description of this cluster of activity provides deep technical insights into the tools and approaches used by the APT and a timeline of activity, providing a rich set of indicators for use by defenders.</p>
<p>Palo Alto Networks customers receive protections against the threats discussed in this article through Advanced WildFire, Advanced URL Filtering, DNS Security, Cortex XDR and Cortex XSIAM, as detailed in the <a href="#post-130156-_mf3k1d3b3om7">conclusion</a>.</p>
<p>Organizations can engage the <a href="https://start.paloaltonetworks.com/contact-unit42.html" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Unit 42 Incident Response</a> team for specific assistance with this threat and others.</p>
<table style="width: 100%; height: 24px;">
<thead>
<tr style="height: 24px;">
<td style="width: 35%; height: 24px;"><b>Related Unit 42 Topics</b></td>
<td style="width: 100%; height: 24px;"><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/government/" target="_blank" rel="noopener"><b>Government</b></a>, <strong><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/apts/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">APTs</a></strong></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 35%;"><b>Alloy Taurus akas</b></td>
<td style="width: 100%;"><b><span style="font-weight: 400;">GALLIUM, Softcell</span></b></td>
</tr>
</thead>
</table>
<h2><a id="post-130156-_gdcph0px9i8r"></a><strong>Timeline of Activity</strong></h2>
<figure id="attachment_130159" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-130159" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-130159" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/09/word-image-130156-1.png" alt="Image 1 is a timeline of CLA-STA-0045. There are six waves of activity in total. The first wave start in quarter 1 of 2022 and continues through quarters two, three and four of 2022, and quarters one through three of 2023. " width="900" height="684" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-130159" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 1. Timeline of CL-STA-0045.</figcaption></figure>
<h2><a id="post-130156-_510pg4a3d1wc"></a><strong>CL-STA-0045 Details</strong></h2>
<h3><a id="post-130156-_qkp7qe7dz0mn"></a>From Web Shell to Interactive Attack</h3>
<p>Each wave of CL-STA-0045 activity started after the attackers gained access to the network and installed several web shells, including China Chopper, on several internet-facing web servers. Using the web shells, the attackers were able to perform an interactive attack that included running reconnaissance commands and tools (e.g., <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;"><a href="https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows-server/administration/windows-commands/whoami" target="_blank" rel="noopener">whoami</a></span>, <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;"><a href="https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows-server/administration/windows-commands/ipconfig" target="_blank" rel="noopener">ipconfig</a></span>, <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;"><a href="https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows-server/administration/windows-commands/dir" target="_blank" rel="noopener">dir</a></span>, <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;"><a href="https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows-server/administration/windows-commands/arp" target="_blank" rel="noopener">arp</a></span> and <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;"><a href="https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/troubleshoot/windows-server/networking/net-commands-on-operating-systems" target="_blank" rel="noopener">net</a></span>, NBTScan) and creating several administrative accounts (named <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">Admin$</span>, <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">Back$</span>, <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">infoma$</span> and <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">testuser</span>).</p>
<p>The attackers used these accounts to perform additional activities, as shown in Figure 2.</p>
<p><figure id="attachment_130161" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-130161" style="width: 802px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-130161" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/09/word-image-130156-2.png" alt="Image 2 is a screenshot of an alert in Cortex XDR. Alert Description: [Redacted] performed 268 new administrative actions in the last twelve hours. This is an uncharacteristically high number of new administrative actions for [redacted]." width="802" height="99" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-130161" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 2. Suspicious administrative actions alert.</figcaption></figure>The attackers also used two scanners. The first was Fscan, which is an open-source internal network scanner written by a Mandarin speaker called “shadow1ng.” Various research organizations have reported multiple Chinese APT groups using this tool. The second scanner was <a href="https://github.com/samyk/webscan" target="_blank" rel="noopener">WebScan</a>, a browser-based network IP scanner and local IP detector.</p>
<h3><a id="post-130156-_2fbyngwp4w68"></a>Undocumented .NET Backdoors</h3>
<p>Following the creation of the users and the reconnaissance activity, the attackers attempted to execute a previously undocumented .NET backdoor, which they named <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">windows.exe</span>. We named this threat Reshell based on its program database (PDB) path.</p>
<p>The attackers configured the backdoor, which is relatively straightforward and simple, to communicate with the IP <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">23.106.122[.]46</span>. This gave the attackers an easy way to execute arbitrary commands remotely.</p>
<figure id="attachment_130163" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-130163" style="width: 361px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-130163" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/09/word-image-130156-3.png" alt="Image 3 is a screenshot of six lines of code. This is the embedded command and control in the Reshell binary." width="361" height="106" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-130163" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 3. Embedded C2 in the Reshell binary.</figcaption></figure>
<p>After Cortex XDR prevented execution of the Reshell backdoor, the attackers likely suspected something was not right and tried to check for the connection using the <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">netstat</span> command. They searched for IP addresses in the range of <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">23.106*</span> and they made a connectivity check, as shown in Figure 4.</p>
<figure id="attachment_130165" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-130165" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-130165" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/09/word-image-130156-4.png" alt="Image 4 is a screenshot of a tree diagram in Cortex XDR. The tree begins with httpd.exe. Some information is redacted. Included are two commands as well as the action Cortex XDR took (blocking)." width="900" height="440" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-130165" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 4. Reshell execution and connectivity check.</figcaption></figure>
<p>The attackers tried to execute another undocumented .NET backdoor, which we call Zapoa. This backdoor opens an HTTP listener, specifically looking for inbound requests to the server that match the following <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">UrlPrefix</span>, which contains a wildcard to match all hostnames within the URL: <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">https://*:443/256509101/</span>.</p>
<p>This backdoor uses the string <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">P88smzTpVBDjwiUv</span> within the HTTP POST data to authenticate its C2. It provides the operator a wide range of capabilities, including:</p>
<ul>
<li>Extracting system information</li>
<li>Running the supplied shell code in a new thread</li>
<li>Running processes</li>
<li>Manipulating the file system</li>
<li>Timestamping files with a supplied date</li>
<li>Loading additional .NET assembly to enhance its capabilities</li>
</ul>
<h3><a id="post-130156-_jhbtyw8wlqfs"></a>Preparing the Ground</h3>
<p>The attackers continued to perform additional activities to maintain a foothold in the environment. To prepare the ground, bypass security mitigation efforts and hide from the security team, the attackers installed SoftEther VPN software.</p>
<p>The attacker renamed the SoftEther VPN file to <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">Taskllst.exe</span>, as shown in Figure 5. In other instances, they renamed it to <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">fonts.exe</span> and <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">vmtools.exe</span>.</p>
<p>Using this software, the attackers connected to different hosts inside and outside the network such as GitHub (as observed in Figure 5). They also downloaded additional tools such as Kerbrute, LsassUnhooker and GoDumpLsass, which they used in the next phase of the attack.</p>
<figure id="attachment_130167" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-130167" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-130167" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/09/word-image-130156-5.png" alt="Image 5 is a screenshot of a table in Cortex XDR. The column are, from left to right, Source Process Name, Source Signer, and Destination Host. Two .exe files are listed. The signer for both is the SoftEther corporation. The destination host is GitHub." width="900" height="152" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-130167" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 5. Connection to GitHub by SoftEther VPN - <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">taskllst.exe</span>.</figcaption></figure>
<h3><a id="post-130156-_l7ys6dobhscl"></a>Stealing Credentials</h3>
<p>Since the attackers had already gained a local administrator account, the next step was to gain domain credentials to move laterally inside the network. To do so, the attackers tried different techniques and tools.</p>
<ul>
<li><strong>Brute Forcing Credentials:</strong> As shown in Figure 6, the attackers tried to brute force different usernames and passwords using Kerbrute. They used this tool to quickly brute force and enumerate valid Active Directory accounts through Kerberos pre-authentication.</li>
</ul>
<figure id="attachment_130169" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-130169" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-130169" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/09/word-image-130156-6.png" alt="Image 6 is a screenshot of a tree diagram in Cortex XDR. The tree begins with httpd.exe. Some information is redacted. Included are two commands as well as the action Cortex XDR took (blocking)." width="900" height="403" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-130169" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 6. Detection and prevention of Kerbrute and GoDumpLsass execution.</figcaption></figure>
<ul>
<li><strong>Save SAM Key Hive: </strong>The attackers created a scheduled task named <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">updatevmtoolss</span>, which they set to run a <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">.bat</span> file that executes a command to steal credentials from the Security Account Manager (SAM) registry key hive. Figure 7 shows the execution for this activity.</li>
<li><strong>Locally Stored Passwords:</strong> The attackers tried to steal stored passwords. To do so, they ran the <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">cmdkey /l</span> command that lists the stored usernames and passwords. They then tried to access the login data folders of Chrome and searched within configuration files for <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">password=</span>.</li>
</ul>
<p><img decoding="async" class="aligncenter wp-image-130171" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/09/word-image-130156-7.png" alt="A string of code that allows an attacker to search for passwords within configuration files." width="500" height="45" /></p>
<ul>
<li><strong>Dumping Lsass:</strong> The attackers tried to dump the <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">Lsass</span> process using the <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">procdump</span> tool.</li>
</ul>
<p><img decoding="async" class="aligncenter wp-image-130173" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/09/word-image-130156-8.png" alt="A string of code to dump the Lsass process." width="500" height="25" /></p>
<p>The attackers also tried other tools to dump the <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">Lsass</span> process, including the following:</p>
<ul>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">LsassUnhooker</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">TaskManager</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">GoDumpLsass</span> (named <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">123.exe</span>)</li>
<li><strong>Mimikatz:</strong> The attackers tried using the credential harvesting tool Mimikatz.</li>
<li><strong>LaZagne:</strong> The attackers tried using the open source local password extractor tool named LaZagne.</li>
<li><strong>NTLM Downgrade Attack:</strong> Finally, the attackers tried a less common method of stealing credentials, which was to <a href="https://www.hackingarticles.in/ntlm-downgrade-attack-internal-monologue/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">downgrade the Windows New Technology LAN Manager (NTLM) version</a> to extract the NTLM hashes. To do so, the attackers used the tool <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">InternalMonologue.exe</span> and changed related registry values, as shown in Figure 7.</li>
</ul>
<figure id="attachment_130175" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-130175" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-130175" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/09/word-image-130156-9.png" alt="Image 7 is a screenshot of a tree diagram in Cortex XDR. Some information is redacted. The tree splits once and has four branches. Included are the commands used by the threat actor. The main action prevented is InternalMonologue.exe. " width="900" height="506" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-130175" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 7. Detection and prevention of NTLM downgrade attack and credential theft.</figcaption></figure>
<h3><a id="post-130156-_obqlhda6s6bn"></a>Targeting Critical Assets</h3>
<p>After obtaining credentials, the attackers attempted to move laterally inside the network, aiming specifically at web servers and domain controllers.</p>
<p>The attackers first tried using the SoftEther VPN, attempting to create connections to the targets on SMB (port 445). Later in the attack, the attackers changed their tactic and moved laterally by abusing the remote administration tool AnyDesk. This tool was already present in the compromised environment.</p>
<p>The attackers set the password for AnyDesk to be <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">J9kzQ2Y0qO</span>, which is the same password reported multiple times as being used in <a href="https://michaelkoczwara.medium.com/conti-ransomware-group-cobalt-strike-c2-analysis-rdp-persistence-cc535d35eaba" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Conti ransomware attacks</a>.</p>
<p><img decoding="async" class="aligncenter wp-image-130177" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/09/word-image-130156-10.png" alt="Command line to set password" width="500" height="40" /></p>
<p>We observed no attempt to execute ransomware.</p>
<h3><a id="post-130156-_2r1eknkmjr1v"></a>Installing Additional Tools</h3>
<p>In addition to the already installed tools mentioned above, the attackers attempted to install other tools and malware to help perform malicious activities and maintain a foothold in the environment. Among these tools were the following:</p>
<ul>
<li>Cobalt Strike</li>
<li>PuTTY's Plink</li>
<li>HTran</li>
<li>Quasar remote access Trojan (RAT)</li>
</ul>
<h4><a id="post-130156-_g3tlq6xqctd8"></a>Cobalt Strike</h4>
<p>The attackers attempted to create a connection to the domain <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">images.cdn-sina[.]tw</span> to download a file named <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">scvhost.txt</span>. This file was a Cobalt Strike beacon, which Figure 8 shows Cortex XDR prevented from executing.</p>
<p><figure id="attachment_130179" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-130179" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-130179" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/09/word-image-130156-11.png" alt="Image 8 is a screenshot of a tree diagram in Cortex XDR. The tree splits once and has four branches. Included are the commands used by the threat actor. Two actions are prevented: scvhost.text and result.txt." width="900" height="548" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-130179" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 8. Blocked execution of payloads from <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">images.cdn-sina[.]tw</span>.</figcaption></figure>In another attempt to execute Cobalt Strike, the attackers created services to run the beacon (<span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">Reset.cpl</span>, <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">help.exe</span>) using the <a href="https://lolbas-project.github.io/lolbas/Libraries/Shell32/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">living-off-the-land binaries and scripts (LOLBAS) method</a> of abusing the Windows Shell Common DLL (<span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">Shell32.dll</span>), as highlighted in the below code snippet and shown in full in Figure 9.</p>
<p><img decoding="async" class="aligncenter wp-image-130181" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/09/word-image-130156-12.png" alt="A string of code that abuses Shell32.dll. " width="500" height="37" /></p>
<figure id="attachment_130183" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-130183" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-130183" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/09/word-image-130156-13.png" alt="Image 9 is a screenshot of a tree diagram in Cortex XDR. The tree splits once and has three branches. Included are the commands used by the threat actor. The execution of Cobalt Strike is blocked. " width="900" height="481" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-130183" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 9. Blocked execution of Cobalt Strike by abusing the Windows Shell Common DLL.</figcaption></figure>
<h4><a id="post-130156-_981jwotvqa4p"></a>Reverse SSH Tunneling</h4>
<p>Attackers established a reverse Secure Shell (SSH) tunnel that allowed direct Remote Desktop Protocol (RDP) connection to the compromised host so they could interact with AnyDesk remotely. To do this, the attackers tried to use HTran (<span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">lcx.111</span>) to tunnel RDP connections to its C2 (<span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">154.55.128[.]129</span>, as shown in Figure 10).</p>
<p>In an attempt to overcome the mitigation efforts, the attackers also tried using another tool to perform this SSH tunneling called PuTTY. The attackers downloaded a file named <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">result.txt</span> from the same domain mentioned above (<span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">images.cdn-sina[.]tw</span>), which is the PuTTY binary.</p>
<p>Using the PuTTY binary in one compromised environment, the attackers attempted to create an SSH tunnel to <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">159.223.85[.]37</span>. In another compromised environment, the attackers tried to tunnel to both that IP and <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">156.251.162[.]29</span>.</p>
<p>The attackers kept using those tools, sometimes with the same naming convention and the same infrastructure, across multiple victims in the government sector in the Southeast Asian country.</p>
<figure id="attachment_130185" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-130185" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-130185" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/09/word-image-130156-14.png" alt="Image 10 is a screenshot of a tree diagram with two branches in Cortex XDR. This demonstrates the program detection and then preventing the execution of HTran and Plink. Some information has been redacted. " width="900" height="238" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-130185" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 10. Detection and prevention of HTran and Plink execution.</figcaption></figure>
<h4><a id="post-130156-_gcoxf1wfapk4"></a>Downloading Additional Tools via PowerShell</h4>
<p>In addition to Cobalt Strike and PuTTY, which the attackers downloaded from <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">images.cdn-sina[.]tw</span>, they also used another subdomain (<span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">Shell.cdn-sina[.]tw</span>, resolved to <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">78.142.246[.]117</span>). Attackers used it to store additional tools including victim-specific scripts.</p>
<p>To access those tools, the attackers used Windows Management Instrumentation (WMI) and PowerShell with the following command line.</p>
<p><img decoding="async" class="aligncenter wp-image-130187" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/09/word-image-130156-15.png" alt="A string of code used to access stored additional tools." width="600" height="77" /></p>
<p>Attackers tried to bypass some antivirus detection of download string operations (i.e., searching for certain keywords, such as <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">DownloadString</span>).</p>
<p>The attackers also downloaded <a href="https://malpedia.caad.fkie.fraunhofer.de/details/win.powercat" target="_blank" rel="noopener">PowerCat</a> (the PowerShell version of the networking utility <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Netcat" target="_blank" rel="noopener">netcat</a>) from the same domain, using the IP this time. They then ran this utility with the same IP previously used by the attackers as a parameter for Plink.</p>
<p><img decoding="async" class="aligncenter wp-image-130189" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/09/word-image-130156-16.png" alt="A string of code to run the utility netcat." width="600" height="83" /></p>
<h4><a id="post-130156-_q4uj8t7ud7lu"></a>Quasar RAT</h4>
<p>Another type of malware that the attackers attempted to use is Quasar RAT. Different threat actors around the world use this off-the-shelf tool. The malware provides its operator with a wide set of capabilities, including the following:</p>
<ul>
<li>Capturing screenshots</li>
<li>Recording the victim’s webcam</li>
<li>Keylogging</li>
<li>Stealing passwords</li>
</ul>
<p>As observed in Figure 11, the actor put the Quasar RAT dropper (<span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">l.exe</span>) in the <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">C:/Recovery</span> folder, which dropped the Quasar RAT loader (<span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">loader.any</span>) and tried to execute it.</p>
<figure id="attachment_130191" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-130191" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-130191" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/09/word-image-130156-17.png" alt="Image 11 is a screenshot of a tree diagram in Cortex XDR. The tree splits once and has two branches. Two actions are prevented (blocked). These are l.exe and regsvr32.exe Loader.any." width="900" height="358" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-130191" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 11. Prevention of Quasar RAT execution.</figcaption></figure>
<h4><a id="post-130156-_si2z5w5cz918"></a>HDoor</h4>
<p>The attacker also used a customized version of the Chinese backdoor <a href="https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0061/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">HDoor</a>. HDoor has been publicly available in Chinese forums since at least 2008. Various research organizations have reported that multiple Chinese APT groups have used this threat, such as <a href="https://media.kasperskycontenthub.com/wp-content/uploads/sites/43/2018/03/07205555/TheNaikonAPT-MsnMM1.pdf" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Growing Taurus</a> (aka Naikon) and <a href="https://www.securityweek.com/chinese-hackers-target-air-gapped-systems-custom-usb-malware/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Parched Taurus</a> (aka Goblin Panda).</p>
<p>HDoor is equipped with full backdoor capabilities, allowing the operator to perform a <a href="https://huaidan.org/archives/2135.html" target="_blank" rel="noopener">variety of tasks</a>, including the following:</p>
<ul>
<li>Keylogging</li>
<li>File and process manipulation</li>
<li>Scanning</li>
<li>Acting as a proxy client</li>
<li>Connecting to other endpoints in the network</li>
<li>Stealing credentials in various methods</li>
<li>Exfiltrating data</li>
</ul>
<p>HDoor was executed using the following command line arguments:</p>
<p><img decoding="async" class="aligncenter wp-image-130193" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/09/word-image-130156-18.png" alt="A string of code to execute Hdoor." width="500" height="30" /></p>
<h4><a id="post-130156-_aer8tpf8xygf"></a>Gh0stCringe RAT</h4>
<p>Another piece of malware that the attackers tried to use is <a href="https://asec.ahnlab.com/en/32572/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Gh0stCringe</a>, which is based on the source code of Gh0st RAT. The attackers tried to execute this tool twice, with a gap of over 10 days between executions.</p>
<p>In the first execution, the attackers attempted to execute the malware dropper, which was named <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">Cssrs.exe</span>. This dropped the Gh0stCringe binary, named <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">moon.exe</span>, and executed it. Figure 12 shows this activity.</p>
<figure id="attachment_130195" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-130195" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-130195" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/09/word-image-130156-19.png" alt="Image 12 is a screenshot of a diagram in Cortex XDR. The execution of moon.exe is blocked." width="900" height="208" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-130195" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 12. Gh0stCringe process tree.</figcaption></figure>
<p>The second time, the attackers tried to execute Gh0stCringe by the name <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">conhost.exe</span> as shown in Figure 13. They created the malware under the ESET folder <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">C:\ProgramData\ESET\RemoteAdministrator\Agent\conhost.exe</span>.</p>
<p>Although this folder is legitimate and contains ESET-related files that were legitimately installed in the victim’s environment, the use of this folder to store malicious payloads is not common.</p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">However, we note that in the same environment, we saw the threat actors behind a different cluster, </span><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/stately-taurus-attacks-se-asian-government"><span style="font-weight: 400;">CL-STA-0044</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;"> abusing </span><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">ERAAgent.exe</span><span style="font-weight: 400;"> to execute the ToneShell malware.</span></p>
<figure id="attachment_130197" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-130197" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-130197" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/09/word-image-130156-20.png" alt="Image 13 is a screenshot of a tree diagram in Cortex XDR. The tree splits once and has two branches. Included are the commands used by the threat actor. The commands used by the attackers are included. The execution of conhost.exe is blocked. Some information is redacted. " width="900" height="353" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-130197" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 13. Executing Gh0stCringe from the ESET folder.</figcaption></figure>
<h4><a id="post-130156-_9irxkfgdp240"></a>A Variant of the Winnti Malware</h4>
<p>In January 2023, we observed the actors attempting to install a variant of the Winnti malware family. According to an April 11, 2013, <a href="https://securelist.com/winnti-more-than-just-a-game/37029/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">blog written by Kaspersky</a>, Winnti is a prominent malware family used by multiple Chinese threat groups since at least 2011.</p>
<p>To install this particular variant of Winnti, the actor saved two files (<span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">rs.exe</span> and <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">s.dll</span>) to the system within the folder <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">D:\HPEOneView\&lt;redacted&gt;\admin\.!\.dump</span>. The <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">rs.exe</span> executable is a loader that copies the <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">s.dll</span> payload to the location <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">%SYSTEM%\lscsrv.dll</span> and creates a service named <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">Lscsrv</span> with it.</p>
<p>This beacon leads us to believe this is a variant of the Winnti malware. This beacon has several overlaps compared to the beacon created by the Winnti malware discussed in Kaspersky’s blog:</p>
<ul>
<li>The first four bytes within the beacon data are hard-coded as <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">0xDF1F1ED3</span>.</li>
<li>The beacon data is 1,360 bytes in length before compression.</li>
<li>The beacon data is compressed using <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">zlib</span> with a compression level of 8.</li>
<li>The packet structure is the same including:
<ul>
<li>the compressed data length</li>
<li>a hard-coded null value</li>
<li>a random byte</li>
<li>the compressed data</li>
</ul>
</li>
<li>The structure of the beacon data itself is identical, with the field types at the same offsets</li>
</ul>
<p>At a high level, this Winnti variant has the following capabilities available for the actor to use:</p>
<ul>
<li>File system modifications</li>
<li>Registry modifications</li>
<li>Service modifications</li>
<li>Uploading and downloading of files</li>
<li>Creating and acting as a proxy</li>
<li>Reverse shell</li>
<li>Keylogging</li>
<li>Screen control functionality, including key typing and mouse movement</li>
<li>Enumerating network resources and file shares</li>
</ul>
<h2><a id="post-130156-_dqa6t9udp4iq"></a><strong>Attribution</strong></h2>
<p>We identified CL-STA-0045 activity on multiple entities of the same government in Southeast Asia around the same time frame. The clustering of the activity was based on the use of the same tools, malware, similar techniques and tactics, and in some cases shared infrastructure.</p>
<p>Analysis of activity of the threat actor behind CL-STA-0045, in combination with third-party reporting, presents noteworthy overlaps with the reported modus operandi of Alloy Taurus (aka <a href="https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0093/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">GALLIUM</a>).</p>
<p>The threat actor used a combination of tools and malware during its operation that, when grouped together in a single operation, presents a rather unique playbook.</p>
<p>As part of this cluster of activity, some of the main tools used together include the following:</p>
<ul>
<li>The renamed SoftEther VPN using a similar naming convention with files and/or folders</li>
<li>China Chopper web shell being installed after web server exploitation</li>
<li>HTran being used for RDP tunneling</li>
<li>NBTScan</li>
<li>A Gh0st RAT variant being used to establish a foothold</li>
</ul>
<p>The combination of these tools in a single operation has only been previously <a href="https://www.microsoft.com/en-us/security/blog/2019/12/12/gallium-targeting-global-telecom/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">reported as part of Alloy Taurus operations</a>.</p>
<p>In addition, our analysis of the activity showed a repetitive style of attack, in which the threat actor attacked in waves. Each wave started with web server exploitation as well as installation of web shells and reconnaissance. This was then followed by the deployment of additional tools. This manner of operation, with the tools listed above, overlaps with the behavior reported in <a href="https://www.cybereason.com/blog/research/operation-soft-cell-a-worldwide-campaign-against-telecommunications-providers" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Operation SoftCell</a>.</p>
<p>Furthermore, the Unit 42 internal telemetry we’ve presented included an infrastructure overlap with the activity described in CL-STA-0045, and it was observed on one of the compromised entities belonging to the same government. The threat actor behind this cluster used a renamed SoftEther VPN to hide their connection to its C2 server.</p>
<p>In one instance of this activity cluster, the communication we observed was to an infrastructure that overlaps with the IP address <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">196.216.136[.]139</span> that we mentioned in our post <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/alloy-taurus/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Chinese Alloy Taurus Updates PingPull Malware</a>. Our telemetry also suggests that Alloy Taurus was active in the same environment in Q3 and Q4 of 2022, which aligns with CL-STA-0045 activity from a timeline perspective.</p>
<p>We observed the activity specifically associated with CL-STA-0045 targeting the government sector in Southeast Asia. Alloy Taurus was <a href="https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0093/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">previously reported</a> to target the government sector in that region.</p>
<p>The combination of tools used in CL-STA-0045, the analysis of the threat actor’s modus operandi, the victimology of this cluster and overlaps with Unit 42 internal telemetry led us to estimate with a moderate level of confidence that the threat actor behind CL-STA-0045 is likely the Alloy Taurus APT group.</p>
<h2><a id="post-130156-_aw9qcnvsrcv3"></a><strong>Conclusion</strong></h2>
<p>CL-STA-0045 activity represents a significant threat to government entities in South East Asia. The threat actor behind this cluster employed a mature approach, utilizing multiwave intrusions and exploiting vulnerabilities in Exchange Servers as their main penetration vector. We estimate that the main goal behind the activity was to facilitate long-term espionage operations.</p>
<p>Based on the available telemetry, we attribute this cluster of activity with a moderate level of confidence to the Alloy Taurus group. This threat actor poses a significant threat to regional security and warrants heightened attention from affected organizations and governments in the region.</p>
<p>The findings of this investigation underscore the urgent need for enhanced security measures, vigilant monitoring and proactive threat intelligence sharing among government entities and affected industries in Southeast Asia. By adopting a multilayered defense approach and staying informed about emerging threats, organizations can better protect themselves against the persistent and evolving tactics employed by threat actors such as Alloy Taurus.</p>
<h2><a id="post-130156-_mf3k1d3b3om7"></a><strong>Protections and Mitigations</strong></h2>
<p>For Palo Alto Networks customers, our products and services provide the following coverage associated with the threats described above:</p>
<ul>
<li><a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/products/secure-the-network/wildfire?_gl=1*nq7ug8*_ga*NzQyNjM2NzkuMTY2NjY3OTczNw..*_ga_KS2MELEEFC*MTY2OTcyNDAwMC4zMC4xLjE2Njk3MjQwNjEuNjAuMC4w" target="_blank" rel="noopener">WildFire</a> cloud-delivered malware analysis service accurately identifies the known samples as malicious.</li>
<li><a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/network-security/advanced-url-filtering?_gl=1*13pmp8e*_ga*NzQyNjM2NzkuMTY2NjY3OTczNw..*_ga_KS2MELEEFC*MTY2OTczNjA2MS4zMS4wLjE2Njk3MzYwNjEuNjAuMC4w" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Advanced URL Filtering</a> and <a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/network-security/dns-security?_gl=1*13pmp8e*_ga*NzQyNjM2NzkuMTY2NjY3OTczNw..*_ga_KS2MELEEFC*MTY2OTczNjA2MS4zMS4wLjE2Njk3MzYwNjEuNjAuMC4w" target="_blank" rel="noopener">DNS Security</a> identify domains associated with this group as malicious.</li>
<li><a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/cortex/cortex-xdr?_gl=1*13pmp8e*_ga*NzQyNjM2NzkuMTY2NjY3OTczNw..*_ga_KS2MELEEFC*MTY2OTczNjA2MS4zMS4wLjE2Njk3MzYwNjEuNjAuMC4w" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Cortex XDR</a> and <a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/cortex/cortex-xsiam" target="_blank" rel="noopener">XSIAM</a>
<ul>
<li>Prevents the execution of known malicious malware, and also prevents the execution of unknown malware using <a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/products/secure-the-network/subscriptions/threat-prevention?_gl=1*13pmp8e*_ga*NzQyNjM2NzkuMTY2NjY3OTczNw..*_ga_KS2MELEEFC*MTY2OTczNjA2MS4zMS4wLjE2Njk3MzYwNjEuNjAuMC4w" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Behavioral Threat Protection and</a> machine learning based on the Local Analysis module.</li>
<li>Protects against credential gathering tools and techniques using the new Credential Gathering Protection available from Cortex XDR 3.4.</li>
<li>Protects from threat actors dropping and executing commands from web shells using Anti-Webshell Protection, newly released in Cortex XDR 3.4.</li>
<li>Protects against exploitation of different vulnerabilities including ProxyShell and ProxyLogon using the Anti-Exploitation modules as well as Behavioral Threat Protection.</li>
<li>Cortex XDR Pro <a href="https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/cortex/cortex-xdr/cortex-xdr-analytics-alert-reference/cortex-xdr-analytics-alert-reference/analytics-alerts-by-required-data-source" target="_blank" rel="noopener">detects post exploit activity</a>, including credential-based attacks, with behavioral analytics.</li>
</ul>
</li>
</ul>
<p>If you think you may have been impacted or have an urgent matter, get in touch with the <a href="https://start.paloaltonetworks.com/contact-unit42.html?_gl=1*13pmp8e*_ga*NzQyNjM2NzkuMTY2NjY3OTczNw..*_ga_KS2MELEEFC*MTY2OTczNjA2MS4zMS4wLjE2Njk3MzYwNjEuNjAuMC4w" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Unit 42 Incident Response team</a> or call:</p>
<ul>
<li>North America Toll-Free: 866.486.4842 (866.4.UNIT42)</li>
<li>EMEA: +31.20.299.3130</li>
<li>APAC: +65.6983.8730</li>
<li>Japan: +81.50.1790.0200</li>
</ul>
<p>Palo Alto Networks has shared these findings, including file samples and indicators of compromise, with our fellow Cyber Threat Alliance (CTA) members. CTA members use this intelligence to rapidly deploy protections to their customers and to systematically disrupt malicious cyber actors. Learn more about the <a href="https://www.cyberthreatalliance.org" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Cyber Threat Alliance</a>.</p>
<h2><a id="post-130156-_ydqdbjg0dngh"></a><strong>Indicators of Compromise</strong></h2>
<h3><a id="post-130156-_c2o5xs4ygs9d"></a>Web Shells</h3>
<ul>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">b87c125c8c3bf43096690bf74df960e2c0120654635c4ea715039fbe9115ecef</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">009a9d1609592abe039324da2a8a69c4a305ca999920bf6bbef839273516783a</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">C1f43b7cf46ba12cfc1357b17e4f5af408740af7ae70572c9cf988ac50260ce1</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">36e661edc1ad4e44ba38d8f7a6bd00c2b4bc32e9fae8b955b1b4c6355aa6abed</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">6455bb361d1a1246d1df39b0785fc0f370eb54dd7d5b64d70457e4f9881f6c3c</span></li>
</ul>
<h3><a id="post-130156-_30pycp9qmnm3"></a>Reshell Backdoor</h3>
<ul>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">4cb020a66fdbc99b0bce2ae24d5684685e2b1e9219fbdfda56b3aace4e8d5f66</span></li>
</ul>
<h3><a id="post-130156-_pv0t1taybrlo"></a>Zapoa Backdoor</h3>
<ul>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">128bc34ee9d907d017f2e6f8fbbba24c3e51ed5a2fdba417ba893b496c8c18a7</span></li>
</ul>
<h3><a id="post-130156-_vaeigwn6l6b1"></a>Cobalt Strike</h3>
<ul>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">Fec2d328462c944e85dd112e61c97d3e67a39f3c83c59e07410d228c7222d153</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">99d0764248491f44709bd000104f6f99e53c9de8d55649b45112320d7bc4deed</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">9242846351a65655e93ed2aeaf36b535ff5b79ddf76c33d54089d9005a66265b</span></li>
</ul>
<h3><a id="post-130156-_d62r085x54gh"></a>Quasar RAT</h3>
<ul>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">244cb0f526c2c99be0bf822463cd338630afa12ab32cc9b6cfd6e85fa315a478</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">3e5c992b2be98efd3de5b13969900f207665116063a889b1c763371d4104f7f9</span></li>
</ul>
<h3><a id="post-130156-_24wpvgru6e1q"></a>HDoor</h3>
<ul>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">bd5dcf5911f959dd79de046d151e8a4aed3b854a322135acc37e3edb3643d0e2</span></li>
</ul>
<h3><a id="post-130156-_779pt3ox6x71"></a>Gh0stCringe RAT</h3>
<ul>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">f602bd56d6b4bf040956b86ed030643523a8b6611a21b5aafeaa82478820c395</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">d3b8f10f25545bed7d661b6a80be53356c00947800c7e53f050cb15b1f9b953b</span></li>
</ul>
<h3><a id="post-130156-_qn4d6oefvsrp"></a>Winnti-Related Backdoor</h3>
<ul>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">a6b33cf73dd85c18577f58a75802ea0820f11aba88fac23ee3794fac1f4bacfa</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">0d0dd41677ff0d7d648f8563db3a4b4844d86d70562d844bad1983333ae5633d</span></li>
</ul>
<h3><a id="post-130156-_ry8inf6nvhf1"></a>Fscan</h3>
<ul>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">c27f0e68bc7f2ec2eede8a8e08fa341d41d5d2d0fb2b74260679a5504115947e</span></li>
</ul>
<h3><a id="post-130156-_5oecax3g3m44"></a>WebScan</h3>
<ul>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">dbdd0f4bf1f217d794738b7d4f83483a5b3579be8791a7e2f2a62ec3e839be3c</span></li>
</ul>
<h3><a id="post-130156-_kcx4pdz8hapz"></a>Kerbrute</h3>
<ul>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">5aa035ebc3359ee8517d99569c8881fcb7f48ab7e9a2f101f7e7ec23e636c79b</span></li>
</ul>
<h3><a id="post-130156-_rbkuuatloq6o"></a>LsassUnhooker</h3>
<ul>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">225e5818dc7e7b23110f64fbb718c1792ad93ba7eb893bfbee96cdb13180fbf7</span></li>
</ul>
<h3><a id="post-130156-_p7i8reez3ebj"></a>InternalMonologue.exe</h3>
<ul>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">c74897b1e986e2876873abb3b5069bf1b103667f7f0e6b4581fbda3fd647a74a</span></li>
</ul>
<h3><a id="post-130156-_82n7cqhk87c"></a>Infrastructure</h3>
<ul>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">159.223.85[.]37</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">156.251.162[.]29</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">Shell.cdn-sina[.]tw</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">images.cdn-sina[.]tw</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">78.142.246[.]117</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">154.55.128[.]129</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">34.81.11[.]157</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">45.117.103[.]86</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">23.106.122[.]46</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">202.53.148[.]3</span></li>
</ul>
<h3><a id="post-130156-_mfnvekwd5ux"></a>Reshell URI Pattern</h3>
<ul>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">/sbName/</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">/Sleep/hostname=</span></li>
</ul>

</ul>
</li>

              </div>
            </div>
                                <div class="pa l-card l-card--slider"  data-card-link="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/machine-learning-new-swiss-army-suite-tool/" data-video-cta-tracking="alloy-taurus-targets-se-asian-government:related-resources:Detecting Vulnerability Scanning Traffic From Underground Tools Using Machine Learning:card:video-modal:Read the article" data-video-title="Detecting Vulnerability Scanning Traffic From Underground Tools Using Machine Learning">

                <img width="718" height="440" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/01_Tutorial_Category_1505x922-718x440.jpg" class="attachment-medium size-medium" alt="A pictorial representation of machine learning detecting vulnerability scanning.               <div class="card-content">
                <div class="card-content__wrapper">
                  <a class="card-category" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/threat-research/" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="alloy-taurus-targets-se-asian-government:related-resources:Detecting Vulnerability Scanning Traffic From Underground Tools Using Machine Learning:Threat Research"><span class=""><img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/icon-threat-research.svg" alt=" category icon">Threat Research</span></a>                  <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/machine-learning-new-swiss-army-suite-tool/" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="alloy-taurus-targets-se-asian-government:related-resources:Detecting Vulnerability Scanning Traffic From Underground Tools Using Machine Learning">

                                <div class="pa l-card l-card--slider" >
              <div class="card-media " >
                              <figure>
                <img width="786" height="368" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/09-3-Stately-Taurus-1920x900-1-786x368.png" class="attachment-medium size-medium" alt="Pictorial representation of Stately Taurus&#039; updated TTPs.                             </div>
              <div class="card-content">
                <div class="card-content__wrapper">
                  <a class="card-category" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/threat-actor-groups/" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="alloy-taurus-targets-se-asian-government:related-resources:Chinese APT Abuses VSCode to Target Government in Asia:Threat Actor Groups"><span class=""><img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/07/threat-actor-groups.svg" alt=" category icon">Threat Actor Groups</span></a>                  <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/stately-taurus-abuses-vscode-southeast-asian-espionage/" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="alloy-taurus-targets-se-asian-government:related-resources:Chinese APT Abuses VSCode to Target Government in Asia">

              <div class="card-content">
                <div class="card-content__wrapper">
                  <a class="card-category" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/threat-research/" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="alloy-taurus-targets-se-asian-government:related-resources:Spoofed GlobalProtect Used to Deliver Unique WikiLoader Variant:Threat Research"><span class=""><img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/icon-threat-research.svg" alt=" category icon">Threat Research</span></a>                  <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/global-protect-vpn-spoof-distributes-wikiloader/" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="alloy-taurus-targets-se-asian-government:related-resources:Spoofed GlobalProtect Used to Deliver Unique WikiLoader Variant">

<!--  Start: Footer subscription form -->
<div class="newsletter">
      <div class="l-container">
        <div class="newsletter__wrapper">
          <div class="image__wrapper"> 
            <picture>
			              	 <source media="(max-width:400px)" srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/newsletter-Image-mobile.webp">
			  			               	 <source media="(max-width:949px)" srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/newsletter-Image-tab.webp">
			  			  			  	<img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/Revitalized_newsletter-Image-desktop-copy-1.webp" alt="Newsletter">
			              </picture>
          </div>
          <div class="content__wrapper"> 
		    							<span class="pre-title"> 
				<img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/palo-alto-logo-small.svg" alt="UNIT 42 Small Logo">
				Get updates from Unit 42			</span>
						           	 <h2>Peace of mind comes from staying ahead of threats. Contact us today.</h2>
			            <form action="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/apps/pan/public/formsubmithandler.submitform.json" method="post" novalidate class="subscribe-form" name="Unit42_Subscribe" id="unit42footerSubscription_form">
              <input type="hidden" name="emailFormMask" value="">
              <input type="hidden" value="1086" name="formid">
              <input type="hidden" value="531-OCS-018" name="munchkinId">
              <input type="hidden" value="2141" name="lpId">
              <input type="hidden" value="1203" name="programId">
              <input type="hidden" value="1086" name="formVid">
              <input type="hidden" name="mkto_optinunit42" value="true">
              <input type="hidden" name="mkto_opt-in" value="true">
              <div class="form-group"> 
                <label for="newsletter-email"  id="newsletter-email-label">Your Email</label>
                <input type="emal" placeholder="Your Email" name="Email"  class="subscribe-field" id="newsletter-email" aria-labelledby="newsletter-email-label">
                <p class="error-mail mb-15 text-danger" style="color: #dc3545"></p>
				<p>Subscribe for email updates to all Unit 42 threat research.<br />By submitting this form, you agree to our <a title="Terms of Use" href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/legal-notices/terms-of-use" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="Get updates from Unit 42:Terms of Use">Terms of Use</a> and acknowledge our <a title="Privacy Statement" href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/legal-notices/privacy" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="Get updates from Unit 42:Privacy Statement">Privacy Statement.</a></p>
                <div class="g-recaptcha" data-expired-callback="captchaExpires" data-callback="captchaComplete" data-sitekey="6Lc5EhgTAAAAAJa-DzE7EeWABasWg4LKv-R3ao6o"></div>
                <p class="error-recaptcha d-none mt-15 text-danger" style="color: #dc3545">Invalid captcha!</p>
                <button class="l-btn is-disabled" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="footer:Get updates from Unit 42:Subscribe" id="unit42footerSubscription_form_button"> 
					Subscribe					<img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/right-arrow.svg" alt="Right Arrow"  class="arrow">
					<img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/icon-loader.svg" alt="loader" class="loader">
			   </button>
				<div class="form-success-message"></div>
              </div>
            </form>
          </div>
        </div>
      </div>
    </div>

<script>

(function($) {
	// Migrated from the unit42-v5 + Modifications
	var subscribeSuccess = false;
	var email = document.getElementById('newsletter-email');
	var subscription_form = document.getElementById('unit42footerSubscription_form');
	var subscription_form_button = document.getElementById('unit42footerSubscription_form_button');
	window.captchaComplete = function() {
		subscribeSuccess = true;
		if ($(mail).val() != '' && isEmail($(mail).val())) {
			$(subscription_form_button).removeClass('is-disabled');
		}
		setTimeout(function() {
			$(email).focus();
			$('.g-recaptcha iframe').attr('tabindex', '-1');
		}, 100)
	}
	window.captchaExpires = function() {
		subscribeSuccess = false;
		$(subscription_form_button).addClass('is-disabled', true);
	} 
	$(subscription_form).submit(function(e) {
		e.preventDefault();
		e.stopImmediatePropagation();
		updateEmailMask();
		var success = true;
		var form = $(this);
		var mail = form.find('input[name="Email"]');
		
		if (mail.val() === '') {
			mail.addClass('has-error');
			showError(1);
			success = false;	
		}  else if (!isEmail(mail.val())){
			showError(2);
			success = false;
		}
		else {
			mail.removeClass('has-error');
			$('.error-mail').addClass('d-none');
		}

		if (!subscribeSuccess) {
			$('.error-recaptcha').removeClass('d-none');
		} else {
			$('.error-recaptcha').addClass('d-none');
		}

		if (success && subscribeSuccess) {
			$.ajax({
				type: 'POST',
				url: form.attr('action'),
				data: form.serialize(),
				beforeSend: function() {
                 form.find('button').addClass('is-loading');
    			},
				success: function(msg) {
					form.find('.form-success-message').html('<p class="success-message">You have been successfully subscribed</p>');
					form.find('button').removeClass('is-loading');
					$(email).val('');
					clearError();
				},
				error: function(jqXHR, textStatus, errorThrown) {
					$(subscription_form_button).addClass('is-disabled', true);
					form.find('button').removeClass('is-loading');
					
				}
			});
		}
		return false;
	});
	function showError(error_type){
		if(error_type == 1) {
			$('.error-mail').text("Please enter the email address.").addClass('error-show');
			$(subscription_form_button).addClass('is-disabled');
		} else if(error_type == 2){
			$('.error-mail').text("Please provide a valid e-mail address.").addClass('error-show');
			$(subscription_form_button).addClass('is-disabled');
		}	
		$(subscription_form_button).removeClass('is-loading');
	}
	function clearError(){
		$('.error-mail').text("").removeClass('error-show');;
		$(subscription_form_button).removeClass('is-loading');
		$(subscription_form_button).removeClass('is-disabled');
	}
	
	$(email).on('input', function (event) { 
		var email = $(this).val();
		if (isEmail(email) ) {			
			clearError();
		} else if(email == ""){
			clearError();
		} else{
			showError(2);			  
		}
    });

	function isEmail(email) {
		var re = /^(([^<>()\[\]\\.,;:\s@"]+(\.[^<>()\[\]\\.,;:\s@"]+)*)|(".+"))@((\[[0-9]{1,3}\.[0-9]{1,3}\.[0-9]{1,3}\.[0-9]{1,3}\])|(([a-zA-Z\-0-9]+\.)+[a-zA-Z]{2,}))$/;
		return re.test(String(email).toLowerCase());
	}
	
	var captcha_loaded = false;
         if(!captcha_loaded){
            // recaptcha on foucs call
            $(document).on('change paste keyup', '#newsletter-email', function () {
               if($('.g-recaptcha').hasClass('d-none')){
                $('.g-recaptcha').removeClass('d-none');
               }
               if(!captcha_loaded ){
                  captcha_loaded  = true;
                  // trigger loading api.js (recaptcha.js) script
                  var head = document.getElementsByTagName('head')[0];
                  var script = document.createElement('script');
                  script.type = 'text/javascript';
                  script.src = 'https://www.google.com/recaptcha/api.js?hl=en_US';
                  head.appendChild(script);
               }
            });
        }
	
	function updateEmailMask() {
		var email = $("#unit42footerSubscription_form input[name='Email']").val();
		if (email && email.trim() != '') {
			var maskedEmail = maskEmailAddress(email);
			$("#unit42footerSubscription_form input[name='emailFormMask']").val(maskedEmail);
		}
	}

	function maskEmailAddress (emailAddress) {
		function mask(str) {
			var strLen = str.length;
			if (strLen > 4) {
				return str.substr(0, 1) + str.substr(1, strLen - 1).replace(/\w/g, '*') + str.substr(-1,1);
			}
			return str.replace(/\w/g, '*');
		}
		return emailAddress.replace(/([\w.]+)@([\w.]+)(\.[\w.]+)/g, function (m, p1, p2, p3) {
			return mask(p1) + '@' + mask(p2) + p3;
		});

		return emailAddress;
	}

}(jQuery));
//# sourceMappingURL=main.js.map
	
</script>
<!--  End: Footer subscription form -->

<footer class="footer"> 
  <div class="footer-menu">

						</li>

							<a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/network-security/strata-cloud-manager"   role="link" title="Strata Cloud Manager" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="footer:Products and services:Network Security Platform:CLOUD DELIVERED SECURITY SERVICES:Advanced Threat Prevention:DNS Security:Data Loss Prevention:IoT Security:Next-Generation Firewalls:Hardware Firewalls:Strata Cloud Manager">Strata Cloud Manager</a>
						</li>

																		<nav>
					<ul class="footer-menu-nav__list">

          </button>

          <div class="modal__post-details" tabindex="-1">       
              <h3>Default Heading</h3>
              <a class="l-btn" href="#" title="Right Arrow Icon" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="overview:explore reports:View all reports">Read the article

              </a>
          </div>

              <label class="is-hidden" for="modalSeekBar">Seekbar</label>

              <p class="modal__remaining-time"></p>
            </div>
            <button class="modal__play-btn is-paused" id="playPauseBtn">
            <img class="play" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/player-play-icon.svg" alt="Play">
            <img class="pause" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/player-pause-icon1.svg" alt="Pause">
          </button>
            <div class="modal__volume-controls">
              <div class="modal__volume__wrapper">
                <button tabindex="0">
                  <img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/icon-volume.svg" alt="Volume">
                </button>
                <div class="modal__volume-seekbar"><span></span>
                  <label class="is-hidden" for="volumeBar">Volume</label>
                  <input class="volume__bar" id="volumeBar" type="range" min="0" max="1" step="0.1" value="0.7">
                </div>
              </div>
              <button class="modal__minimize-btn" id="minimizeBtn">
                <img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/icon-minimize.svg" alt="Minimize">
              </button>
            </div>
          </div>
        </div>
      </div><!--  End: video modal -->

    <script type="text/javascript">
	var isProcessing = false; 
    function alter_ul_post_values(obj,post_id,ul_type){
	
		if (isProcessing)    
		return;  
		isProcessing = true;   
		var like_nonce = jQuery('#_wpnonce').val();
		jQuery(obj).find("span").html("..");
                jQuery.ajax({
                    type: "POST",
                    url: "https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/plugins/like-dislike-counter-for-posts-pages-and-comments/ajax_counter.php",
                    data: "post_id="+post_id+"&up_type="+ul_type+"&ul_nonce="+like_nonce,
                    success: function(msg){
                            jQuery(obj).find("span").html(msg);
                            isProcessing = false; 
                            jQuery(obj).find('svg').children('path').attr('stroke','#0050FF');
                            jQuery(obj).removeClass('idc_ul_cont_not_liked idc_ul_cont_not_liked_inner');
                    }
 		});
	}
	</script>
    <link rel='stylesheet' id='wpdevart_lightbox_front_end_css-css' href='https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/plugins/lightbox-popup/includes/style/wpdevart_lightbox_front.css?ver=6.6.1' media='all' />
<script src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/js/script.js?ver=1.0.0" id="unit42-v6-navigation-js"></script>

<!--  Start: Scripts Migrated From Unit42-v5 -->
<script type="text/javascript">
const observer_lozad = lozad('.lozad, .lozad-background'); // lazy loads elements with default selector as '.lozad'
observer_lozad.observe();

window.PAN_Clean_Util = {
        isIE: false
};

(function () {
   // INP Util Fix
    function yieldToMain(ms) {
        return new Promise(resolve => setTimeout(resolve, ms));
    }
   window.PAN_Clean_Util.yieldToMain = yieldToMain
})();

if(referer == "Prisma" || referer == "Cortex" || referer == "Sase" || referer == "Unit" || referer == "Ngfw"){
  var Coveo_organizationId = "paloaltonetworksintranet";        
  var techDocsPagePath = "https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/search.html#hd=All%20Prisma%20Cloud%20Documentation&hq=%40panproductcategory%3D%3D(%22Prisma%20Cloud%22)&sort=relevancy&layout=card&numberOfResults=25";
  var languageFromPath="en_US";
  window.Granite = window.Granite || {};
  Granite.I18n = (function() {
  var self = {};
  self.setLocale = function(locale) { };
  self.get = function(text, snippets, note) {
    var out = "";
    if(text){
      if(text ==="coveo.clear"){
        out = "Clear";
      }else if(text ==="coveo.noresultsfound"){
        out = "No results found for this search term.";
      }
    }
    return out;
  };
  return self
  }());
}

  var main_site_critical_top = maindomain_lang+'/etc.clientlibs/panClean/components/mainNavigationComp/clientlibs/panClean/criticalTop.min.js';
  var main_site_defered = maindomain_lang+'/etc.clientlibs/panClean/components/mainNavigationComp/clientlibs/panClean/defered.min.js';
  var main_site_criticalTopBase = maindomain_lang+'/etc.clientlibs/panClean/components/mainNavigationComp/clientlibs/panClean/criticalTopBase.min.js';
  var main_site_criticalTopProductNav = maindomain_lang+'/etc.clientlibs/panClean/components/mainNavigationComp/clientlibs/panClean/criticalTopProductNav.min.js';
window.PAN_MainNavAsyncUrl = maindomain_lang+"/_jcr_content/globals/cleanHeaderPrisma.prismaRenderer.html";

function loadScript(url, defer){
    var script1 = document.createElement('script');
    script1.setAttribute('type', 'text/javascript');
    script1.setAttribute('src',url);
    if(defer == true){
        script1.setAttribute('defer','defer');
    }
    document.head.appendChild(script1);
}
function loadScript1(url, callback){

    var script = document.createElement("script")
    script.type = "text/javascript";
    if (script.readyState){  //IE
        script.onreadystatechange = function(){
            if (script.readyState == "loaded" || script.readyState == "complete"){
                script.onreadystatechange = null;
                callback();
            }
        };
    } else {  //Others
        script.onload = function(){
            callback();
        };
    }
    script.src = url;
    document.getElementsByTagName("head")[0].appendChild(script);
}
if(referer == "Prisma" || referer == "Cortex" || referer == "Sase" || referer == "Unit" || referer == "Ngfw"){
	if(referer == "Unit"){
    setTimeout(function(){
      loadScript(main_site_criticalTopBase, false);
      loadScript1(main_site_criticalTopProductNav, function(){
        window.PAN_initializeProduct2021Nav();
      });
      loadScript(main_site_defered, false);
    }, 3000);
	}
	else{
    setTimeout(function(){
      loadScript1(main_site_critical_top, function(){
        window.PAN_initializeProduct2021Nav();
      });
      loadScript(main_site_defered, false);
    }, 3000);
	}
}

$(document).ready(function () {
    setTimeout(function(){
      $('.article-banner .ab__options ul li a').each(function(){
          	$(this).attr('target', "_blank");
      });
    }, 4000);
});
</script>
<!--  End: Scripts Migrated From Unit42-v5 -->
